  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** Integer values.

  18.     Integers are {!Sys.int_size} bits wide and use two's complement
  19.     representation. All operations are taken modulo
  20.     2{^[Sys.int_size]}. They do not fail on overflow.

  22.     @since 4.08 *)

  24. (** {1:ints Integers} *)

  26. ‌type t = int
  27. (** The type for integer values. *)

  29. ‌val zero : int
  30. (** [zero] is the integer [0]. *)

  32. ‌val one : int
  33. (** [one] is the integer [1]. *)

  35. ‌val minus_one : int
  36. (** [minus_one] is the integer [-1]. *)

  38. external neg : int -> int = "%negint"
  39. (** [neg x] is [~-x]. *)

  41. external add : int -> int -> int = "%addint"
  42. (** [add x y] is the addition [x + y]. *)

  44. external sub : int -> int -> int = "%subint"
  45. (** [sub x y] is the subtraction [x - y]. *)

  47. external mul : int -> int -> int = "%mulint"
  48. (** [mul x y] is the multiplication [x * y]. *)

  50. external div : int -> int -> int = "%divint"
  51. (** [div x y] is the division [x / y]. See {!Stdlib.( / )} for details. *)

  53. external rem : int -> int -> int = "%modint"
  54. (** [rem x y] is the remainder [x mod y]. See {!Stdlib.( mod )} for details. *)

  56. external succ : int -> int = "%succint"
  57. (** [succ x] is [add x 1]. *)

  59. external pred : int -> int = "%predint"
  60. (** [pred x] is [sub x 1]. *)

  62. val abs : int -> int
  63. (** [abs x] is the absolute value of [x]. That is [x] if [x] is positive
  64.     and [neg x] if [x] is negative. {b Warning.} This may be negative if
  65.     the argument is {!min_int}. *)

  67. val max_int : int
  68. (** [max_int] is the greatest representable integer,
  69.     [2{^[Sys.int_size - 1]} - 1]. *)

  71. val min_int : int
  72. (** [min_int] is the smallest representable integer,
  73.     [-2{^[Sys.int_size - 1]}]. *)

  75. external logand : int -> int -> int = "%andint"
  76. (** [logand x y] is the bitwise logical and of [x] and [y]. *)

  78. external logor : int -> int -> int = "%orint"
  79. (** [logor x y] is the bitwise logical or of [x] and [y]. *)

  81. external logxor : int -> int -> int = "%xorint"
  82. (** [logxor x y] is the bitwise logical exclusive or of [x] and [y]. *)

  84. val lognot : int -> int
  85. (** [lognot x] is the bitwise logical negation of [x]. *)

  87. external shift_left : int -> int -> int = "%lslint"
  88. (** [shift_left x n] shifts [x] to the left by [n] bits. The result
  89.     is unspecified if [n < 0] or [n > ]{!Sys.int_size}. *)

  91. external shift_right : int -> int -> int = "%asrint"
  92. (** [shift_right x n] shifts [x] to the right by [n] bits. This is an
  93.     arithmetic shift: the sign bit of [x] is replicated and inserted
  94.     in the vacated bits. The result is unspecified if [n < 0] or
  95.     [n > ]{!Sys.int_size}. *)

  97. external shift_right_logical : int -> int -> int = "%lsrint"
  98. (** [shift_right x n] shifts [x] to the right by [n] bits. This is a
  99.     logical shift: zeroes are inserted in the vacated bits regardless
  100.     of the sign of [x]. The result is unspecified if [n < 0] or
  101.     [n > ]{!Sys.int_size}. *)

  103. (** {1:preds Predicates and comparisons} *)

  105. val equal : int -> int -> bool
  106. (** [equal x y] is [true] if and only if [x = y]. *)

  108. val compare : int -> int -> int
  109. (** [compare x y] is {!Stdlib.compare}[ x y] but more efficient. *)

  111. val min : int -> int -> int
  112. (** Return the smaller of the two arguments.
  113.     @since 4.13
  114. *)

  116. val max : int -> int -> int
  117. (** Return the greater of the two arguments.
  118.     @since 4.13
  119. *)

  121. (** {1:convert Converting} *)

  123. external to_float : int -> float = "%floatofint"
  124. (** [to_float x] is [x] as a floating point number. *)

  126. external of_float : float -> int = "%intoffloat"
  127. (** [of_float x] truncates [x] to an integer. The result is
  128.     unspecified if the argument is [nan] or falls outside the range of
  129.     representable integers. *)

  131. (*
  132. val of_string : string -> int option
  133. (** [of_string s] is [Some s] if [s] can be parsed to an integer
  134.     in the range representable by the type [int] (note that this
  135.     depends on {!Sys.int_size}) and [None] otherwise.

  137.     The string may start with an optional ['-'] or ['+'] sign, and may
  138.     be followed by an optional prefix that specifies the base in which
  139.     the number is expressed. If there is not prefix or if the prefix
  140.     is [0u] or [0U] it is expressed in decimal. If the prefix is [0x]
  141.     or [0X] it is expressed in hexadecimal. If the prefix is [0o] or
  142.     [0O] it is expressed in octal. If the prefix is [0b] or [0B] it is
  143.     expressed in binary.

  145.     When the [0u] or [0U] prefix is used, the represented number may
  146.     exceed {!max_int} or {!min_int} in which case it wraps around
  147.     modulo 2{^[Sys.int_size]} like arithmetic operations do.

  149.     The ['_'] (underscore) character can appear anywhere between two
  150.     digits of the number. *)
  151. *)

  153. val to_string : int -> string
  154. (** [to_string x] is the written representation of [x] in decimal. *)

  156. val seeded_hash : int -> int -> int
  157. (** A seeded hash function for ints, with the same output value as
  158.     {!Hashtbl.seeded_hash}. This function allows this module to be passed as
  159.     argument to the functor {!Hashtbl.MakeSeeded}.

  161.     @since 5.1 *)

  163. val hash : int -> int
  164. (** An unseeded hash function for ints, with the same output value as
  165.     {!Hashtbl.hash}. This function allows this module to be passed as argument
  166.     to the functor {!Hashtbl.Make}.

  168.     @since 5.1 *)
